doc.title: August Tokyo CPI—inflation is close to a peak
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Citi/Japan Economics August Tokyo CPIinflation close to a peak August Tokyo CPIinflation close to a peakJapan Economics Augus_2025-08-28

passages.text: In Tokyo, core CPI (excluding only fresh food) increased \(2.6\%\) YoY in August, moderating from a \(2.9\%\) YoY advance in July and matching the consensus. The main factor was slower energy inflation, but core- core CPI also moderated slightly to \(+3.0\%\) YoY. Inflationary expectations have yet to overshoot, and services inflation has hardly accelerated. This situation allows the BoJ to keep an eye on downside risks to economic activities stemming from US tariffs. Meanwhile, the financial market has priced in an October hike to a considerable degree and is now looking beyond the downside risks and focusing on headline inflation that has stayed around \(3\%\) for three consecutive years. It seems the market does not share policymakers' way of thinking. We continue to expect the next rate hike in January 2026.

We estimate nationwide core CPI will increase \(2.8\%\) YoY in August—Based on today's data we estimate August nationwide core CPI (due out September 19) will rise \(2.8\%\) YoY followed by an acceleration to \(+3.1\%\) YoY in September reflecting the base effect of resumed energy subsidies a year ago. Policy factors are expected to make energy inflation volatile in August and September. We expect core CPI inflation to fall below \(3\%\) thereafter. Core- core inflation looks likely to decelerate gradually from a \(3.4\%\) YoY pace in July. We note, however, that the pace of deceleration may well be slower than our projection due to price hikes for food other than rice.
See Appendix A- 1 for Analyst Certification, Important Disclosures and Research Analyst Affiliations.

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

In Tokyo, core CPI (excluding only fresh food) increased 2.6% YoY in August,moderating from a 2.9% YoY advance in July (Figure 1) and matching the consensus. The main factor was slower energy inflation, but core-core CPI also moderated slightly.

The negative contribution of energy to core CPI inflation increased from -0.04ppt in July to -0.30ppt in August. An earlier decline in resource prices and government subsidies contributed to slower energy inflation.

CPI excluding fresh food and energy, i.e., core-core CPI, increased 3.0% YoY in August, down from a 3.1% YoY rise in July and again matching the consensus. Yen appreciation slowed inflation of FX-sensitive consumer durable goods. Food inflation and services inflation were both unchanged. Inflationary expectations have yet to overshoot, and services inflation has hardly accelerated. This situation allows the BoJ to keep an eye on downside risks to economic activities stemming from US tariffs. Meanwhile, the financial market has priced in an October hike to a considerable degree and is now looking beyond the downside risks and focusing on headline inflation that has stayed around 3% for three consecutive years. It seems the market does not share policymakers' way of thinking. We continue to expect the next rate hike in January 2026.
Figure 1. Breakdown of Tokyo core CPI (YoY % for core CPI and core CPI excluding special factors, contribution in ppt for the rest)

Source: Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, Citi Research.
We saw following price movements for principal items in core CPI excluding special factors (see Figure 2).

1. Food other than fresh food: prices increased 7.4% YoY in August, as in July.The contribution to the YoY change in the core CPI also stayed the same at +1.76ppt in August (Figure 2). Inflation for rice prices continued to slow while
Figure 2. Decomposition of contributions to Tokyo core CPI (YoY, %)

Figure 3. Breakdown of services (YoY, %)

\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Note: Services exclude rent and imputed rent, mobile phone charges, hotel charges, and dining out. Source: Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, Citi Research.

Based on today's data we estimate August nationwide core CPI (due out September 19) will rise \(2.8\%\) YoY followed by an acceleration to \(+3.1\%\) YoY in September reflecting the base effect of resumed energy subsidies a year ago. Policy factors look set to make energy inflation volatile in August and September. We expect core CPI inflation to fall below \(3\%\) thereafter. Core- core inflation looks likely to decelerate gradually from a \(3.4\%\) YoY pace in July. However, the pace of deceleration may well be slower than our projection due to price hikes for food other than rice.

The proportion of all Citi Research research recommendations that were the equivalent to "Buy","Hold","Sell" at the end of each quarter over the prior 12 months (with the % of these that had received investment firm services from Citi in the prior 12 months shown in brackets) is as follows: Q2 2025 Buy \(33\%\) (63%), Hold \(44\%\) (51%), Sell \(23\%\) (49%), RV \(0.4\%\) (86%); Q1 2025 Buy \(33\%\) (63%), Hold \(44\%\) (51%), Sell \(23\%\) (49%), RV \(0.5\%\) (87%); Q4 2024 Buy \(32\%\) (64%), Hold \(44\%\) (52%), Sell \(23\%\) (44%), RV \(0.4\%\) (92%); Q3 2024 Buy \(33\%\) (61%), Hold \(44\%\) (52%), Sell \(23\%\) (49%), RV \(0.4\%\) (80%). For the purposes of disclosing recommendations other than for equity (whose definitions can be found in the corresponding disclosure sections), "Buy" means a positive directional trade idea; "Sell" means a negative directional trade idea; and "Relative Value" means any trade idea which does not have a clear direction to the investment strategy.

European regulations require a 5 year price history when past performance of a security is referenced. CitiVelocity's Charting Tool (https://www.citivelocity.com/cv2/#go/CHARTING_3_Equities) provides the facility to create customisable price charts including a five year option. Past performance is not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future results. Forecasts are not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future performance.

Citi Research broadly and simultaneously disseminates its research content to the Firm's institutional and retail clients via the Firm's proprietary electronic distribution platforms (e.g., Citi Velocity and various Global Wealth platforms). As a convenience, certain, but not all, research content may be distributed through third party aggregators. Clients may receive published research reports by email, on a discretionary basis, and only after such research content has been broadly disseminated. Certain research is made available only to institutional investors to satisfy regulatory requirements. The level and types of services provided by Citi Research analysts to clients may vary depending on various factors such as the client's individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communications from analysts, the client's risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g. market- wide, sector specific, long term, short- term etc.), the size and scope of the overall client relationship with the Firm and legal and regulatory constraints.

Further, the selected data represents only a subset of Citi's proprietary credit card transactions due to the selection methodology or other limitations and should not be considered as indicative or predictive of the past or future financial performance of Citi or its credit card business.
